docs.lead_paragraph: Opponents of health care reform periodically argue that legislation is unnecessary because anybody can get medical assistance through the emergency room -- or that those who get in trouble have only themselves for blame by not buying insurance. My Sunday column tells the story of John Brodniak, a young man who had insurance with his job, but lost both when he developed a benign tumor in his brain. Read his story and see if you still think the need for universal coverage isn't urgent. His story seems to me the best rebuttal of the skeptics.

headline.main: The Human Toll of our Health System

docs.abstract: The story of John Brodniak underscores why we need universal health care -- now.
docs.snippet: The story of John Brodniak underscores why we need universal health care -- now.

docs.lead_paragraph: As the Senate begins debate this week on health care legislation, the question of whether to keep the bill's provision for a government-run health insurance plan, known as the public option, will be one of the most contentious.

headline.main: Does the Public Care About the Public Option?

docs.abstract: A careful look at the polls suggests a disconnect between Washington and the public over a government-run health insurance plan.
docs.snippet: A careful look at the polls suggests a disconnect between Washington and the public over a government-run health insurance plan.

docs.lead_paragraph: Stuffed with data and bristling with footnotes, a new report on the federal HealthReform.gov Web site argues ''The Case for Change'' in health insurance. The report includes an interactive map that lets a reader click on any state to see how that state's residents and businesses would benefit -- from the Obama administration's viewpoint, at least -- from an overhaul of the insurance system. The site is operated by the Department of Health and Human Services, whose secretary, Kathleen Sebelius, introduced the report in a conference call this week.

headline.main: 'The Case for Change,' State by State

docs.abstract: New report on federal HealthReform.gov Web site argues 'The Case for Change' in health insurance; report includes interactive map that lets reader click on any state to see how that state's residents and businesses would benefit from overhaul of insurance system; site is operated by Health and Human Services Dept (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: An item in the Prescriptions column on Friday reported the financial problems that pregnancy-related medical bills have posed for Adrienne Schroeder, a young mother of two children, despite having had insurance coverage through her husband's employer or, now, under a plan the Schroeders bought on their own. Here is an sampling of readers' replies: The article describes a very common situation for those not in group plans. As a former sales rep for individual health plans, I used a 145-page guide of exclusions for pre-existing conditions, ''hazardous'' activities and occupations, out-of-limit weight, and use of certain medications. Many of my friends who are covered by company group plans just don't understand the high cost exposure potential and the exorbitant premiums of individual plans which still don't provide coverage for many illnesses. Many holders of such plans are covered for the catastrophic costs, but are reluctant to get the colonoscopy or the CT scans recommended by the doctor because of high deductibles. Not much chance for prevention when you can't afford to pay for it.
docs.abstract: Sampling of readers' replies to Nov 27 item in Prescription column about financial problems that pregnancy-related medical bills have posed for young mother, Adrienne Schroeder, despite her husband's health insurance coverage; drawing (M)
